content: night's game night the best night set up here my players are about to show up and
they're going to continue on where they left off in these mines using the cave
tiles that we built in episode one now I assume all of you have built a set of
these for yourself and if you use them in game and everybody probably loved
them however I'm going to guess that at least a few of your players out there
had one problem where's the where's the door and do and don't understand how you
where this is a wall but where you like it today we're making entranceways if
your players have a hard time visualizing where the doorways are on
this type of setup or if you just want to add a bit more depth to your game
table you might want to make up some of these passageways I kind of spent a lot
of time thinking about the best way to do this first of all it's a cave system
so you're not going to have doors you have openings because the game I'm doing
is being running in mine I figured it would make sense to have these openings
with wood supports just like you see in an old mine shaft I thought about a few
different ways to make them paper mache it would work but if you're like me a um
paper mache do not get along it's too messy too annoying so I made sure to do
it in a way that didn't involve that and also that can be done basically in one
sitting a lot of waiting around for drive times it came out pretty cool you
can customize and make your basic passageways to make ones that are bored
it doesn't make you with webs across it whatever you need
they're really easy to make so let's go back to the workbench and I'll show you
how we made these okay first thing you want to do is grab a piece of tinfoil
about 12 inches by 12 inches and fold it in half twice and then go ahead and
loosely roll that up then go ahead and start bending the
piece of tinfoil into your door opening shape you'll have one side hanging down
longer than the other in a sort of candy cane like shape this long side will give
you something to hold on to when you take your hammer and start flattening
your piece after a few taps on both sides it should be fairly flat and it
will now be quite stiff then you can go ahead and cut off the excess take a
coffee stirrer clip one end and hot glue it to the side and you don't need to
pre-cut these side pieces to length you can glue them on and then cut off the
excess afterwards next mark out the length for the top and
hot glue that one into place once you have that secured take some hot
glue and fill in the gap above the top board repeat on the other side then fill
in the void at the top of the opening with some hot glue next cut out a base
for your door opening out of some thick chipboard couple dabs of hot glue and
you can fix it to the base now you can go around the base and add a bit of
extra hot glue just to make it a little bit more secure now this step is totally
optional you could skip right ahead to paint but I like to take some of this
acrylic latex caulking and coat the surface and fill in the gaps in between
the boards on the opening this will allow your paint to bond much better to
the tinfoil than it would on its own now I'm just using that latex caulking to
fill in the gaps between the boards on the sides and top this will make it look
like one unified piece of lumber then you can go ahead and start filling in
the seams between the wood and the tinfoil and giving the tinfoil a light
coating making sure not to lose any of that detail from the tin foil again this
step is optional but it will make your paint hold a lot better
now grab some PVA glue and thoroughly coat that base take your place and/or
construction sand and cover the glue knocking off the excess now let that dry
out completely and Prime in black then we're going to do a base coat in a dark
gray and before we go and put our light gray
on the stone we're going to brush out all our woodwork in a dark espresso
Brown now you can go ahead and hit those
highlights on the stone with a light gray drybrushing
and the last step is just a bit of dry brushing in a tan on all the wood to
give it a bit of a weathered look and after that it's ready for your table
okay guys I hope you enjoyed this tutorial if you did click below on and
subscribe and join us over on Facebook also if you make any of our projects I
would love to see you post a video send me a link in the comments post pictures
on the DM Scotty board it would be really great to see your take on these I
bet you guys have some awesome ideas okay until next episode
